_prev_prog_3.Description: This prevention program was developed to reduce the probability of a toxic chemical release or explosion incidental to the manufacture of ammonia and urea.  In preparation for commencing operations, HAZOP reviews have been completed for the various operating units.  In addition, an extensive number of process hazard analyses (PHA) have been conducted.
The urea pool reactor uses ammonia under high pressure to manufacture urea.

EPA RMP Submittal:



Executive Summary

Iowa Fertilizer Company (IFCo) is committed to the safety and health of both our community and our workers and to protecting the environment. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in training personnel and promoting safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. Should a release occur, our personnel are trained to respond quickly and effectively to control and mitigate the release.



IFCo was constructed from 2012 forward and began Ammonia production in April of 2017.  



The principal raw materials used are: natural gas (which is delivered by pipeline), air and water.  The facility will manufacture anhydrous ammonia, urea ammonium nitrate (UAN), granular urea, and diesel exhaust fluid (DEF).  Liquid urea, ammonium nitrate, and nitric acid will be produced as intermediate products.  



Anhydrous ammonia is stored at low pressure in two storage tanks that consist of a tank within a tank.  This product will be transported by truck.  All final products will be transported from the facility by either truck or rail.   Granular urea is produced by supplying a pressurized urea solution (typically 97%) into injection heads to produce a finely atomized spray which travels upwards into a circulating bed of granular particles.  Urea formaldehyde solution is injected into this process as an anti-caking agent which allows free product flow, low dust content, and high stability for storage and shipment.



The main process units at IFCo are the Ammonia and Urea processes and supporting facilities.



Description of covered chemicals:

IFCo handles and stores Ammonia, Formaldehyde, Hydrogen, and Methane and mixtures containing these regulated EPA chemicals.



Description of Worst case scenario:

The worst case scenario for toxic chemicals and flammable materials are described in th

e EPA RMP worksheets. EPA's RMP Comp program was utilized to evaluate the worst case scenarios assuming 1.5 meter/sec wind and stability class F.



Description of Alternative Case Scenarios:

The alternate release scenarios for toxic material and flammable material is described in the EPA RMP Worksheets. EPA's RMP Comp program was utilized to evaluate alternative release scenarios assuming 3 meter/sec wind and stability class D.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps: 

The following summary describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program at IFCo. IFCo is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and has procedures and standards for each PSM element. A summary of these programs and standards are listed as below: 



Employee Participation 

IFCo encourages employees and contractors to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Each IFCo department is responsible for ensuring employee participation within their department. The management system policy for each PSM element identifies responsibilities that are more specific. Examples of employee participation include involvement in pre-startup safety reviews, process hazard analysis, job hazard analysis, reviewing procedures, participation in training and incident investigations. In addition, IFCo has a safety committee and town hall meeting forums during which employees and contractors can address both process safety and occupational safety issues. 



Process Safety Information 

IFCo maintains information pertaining to the highly hazardous materials used or produced at the facility, the technology of the processes, and the equipment used. Information is readily available and is updated when changes are made in accordance with management of change procedures.  Safety Data Sheets and other various technical documents are used to facilitate safe operation of the processes. The documents address limits for key

process parameters, safe operating limits, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. 



Process Hazard Analysis 

IFCo conducts scheduled evaluations of the safety of all processes and related facilities within its boundary limits to ensure safe operation and prevent potential catastrophic releases of hazardous materials. Potential offsite consequences are considered as part of this evaluation. IFCo currently uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) method of analysis. Each analysis is conducted by a cross-functional team and facilitated by someone familiar with both IFCo and HAZOP methodology. 



As safety concerns are evaluated, they are ranked according to probability and consequence. All concerns are documented as part of the HAZOP process. Safety concerns that warrant action are formally documented as recommendations and passed on to an individual or department that will be responsible for resolution.  The PSM group manages tracking of the Process Hazards Analysis action items to completion.



The site process hazard analysis guidelines requires a periodic review at least every five years which must continue throughout the life of the process. The results of these updates are documented and retained for the life of the process. Updated findings are stewarded for resolution and tracked.



Operating Procedures 

IFCo has developed and compiled a comprehensive set of operating procedures to provide instruction for the safe operation of IFCo processes. Procedures provide a reliable and consistent reference for all phases of process operations including: 1) unit startup, 2) normal operations, 3) temporary operations, 4) emergency shutdown, 5) normal shutdown, 6) initial startup of a new process, 7) emergency operations, and 8) startup following an abnormal or emergency shutdown. 

Each procedure developed is reviewed for accuracy, consistency, and completeness. Each procedure contains procedure steps, operating parameter

s and limits, safety and health hazard information, safety control measures, and assignment of responsibility for performing the procedure. Operating procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified per site operating procedure standards.



Training 

IFCo has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process or utility. Operators receive classroom, field training, exercise and simulation training. Operators are required to demonstrate their knowledge through tests, skill demonstrations and have adequate knowledge to perform job duties and tasks in a safe manner. Refresher training is conducted at least every three years or more often if needed. All training information is documented. 



Contractors 

IFCo has developed a Contractor Safety Program to satisfy PSM guidelines by extending plant safety requirements to non-IFCo employees working within the site. The Program is intended to maintain a plant-wide, consistent level of safe work performance. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, IFCo has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform IFCo personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work. In addition, IFCo evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractors. IFCo personnel periodically monitor through audits contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) 

IFCo conducts a pre-

startup safety review (PSSR) any time new equipment or modifications to existing equipment change the associated process safety information. The review is intended to verify and document that all aspects of the equipment's design, construction and operation have been evaluated, and to ensure readiness that the equipment can be placed in operation. The PSSR team uses checklists and field verification of construction to examine all aspects of readiness. The PSSR is the final step in the construction or installation of new or modified equipment before the equipment is placed in service.



PSSR procedure ensures that 1) Construction is per design and safety system are tested per design; 2) Operating, maintenance, and emergency response procedures updated and readily available; 3) Affected personnel are trained or notified as necessary; 4) Process Hazard Analysis is conducted and all prestart up related action items are complete; 5) Post start up punch list items are documented and tracked for completion; 6) Management of Change (MOC) process is followed; 7) Accurate red-line Process Safety information is readily available; and 7) The "change" is authorized.



Mechanical Integrity 

IFCo has well-established practices and procedures to maintain ongoing integrity of process equipment. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests per Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP), (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. 



Work is performed under the supervision of a maintenance craft supervisor. Maintenance personnel follow Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) industry standards and equipment specifications during maintenance activities. Written safety procedures

are followed for specific job tasks (i.e. line openings). A Job Safety Analysis (JSA) is conducted for maintenance jobs that are non-routine or may be different due to variables in the operation (i.e. hot taps or work on flare line.) 



Safe Work Practices 

IFCo has written programs for safe work practices to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include 1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, 2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, 3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials prior to opening process piping or equipment, 4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), and 5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures (and others), along with training, help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. 



Management of Change 

Any modification that creates a change in existing process safety information and change in equipment must go through a documented process of verification. The management of change (MOC) process is a system of checks and balances and performing adequate reviews by knowledgeable personnel to ensure safe operation of the process. The process also ensures that all affected process safety information is updated to reflect the change, and that the safety of the modification has been evaluated before startup. 



Incident Investigation and Event Notices 

IFCo has a procedure that requires an investigation of all incidents which resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personnel injury within 48 hours. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  As per the procedure, the formal report is presente

d and distributed at the conclusion of the investigation. Each recommendation arising from the investigation is assigned and tracked until it is resolved. Resolution to each recommendation is documented and retained. 



Compliance Audits 

As per the site Compliance Audit procedure, at least once every three years IFCo is subject to a compliance audit. The audit team will include at least one employee knowledgeable in IFCo and in the audit process. At the conclusion of the audit, the audit team submits a report to IFCo. IFCo management makes appropriate responses to each finding in the report, and takes steps necessary to correct any deficiencies detected by the audit. Resolution of the audit findings is documented. As required by 29 CFR 1910.119(o), IFCo retains the two most recent audit reports. 



Trade Secrets 

IFCo withholds no information necessary for employees to safely carry out their assigned job tasks. If necessary, IFCo management may require a confidentiality agreement with certain employees and contractors in order to protect trade secrets or other proprietary information.





Chemical Specific Prevention Program 



The processes at IFCo involve hazards that must be managed to ensure constant safe operation. The accident prevention program is applied to all RMP-covered processes at IFCo. Collectively, these activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failure and/or human error. In addition to the accident prevention program activities, IFCo has safety features on many units to help 1) contain/control a release, 2) quickly detect a release, and 3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. 



The following types of safety features are used in various processes: 



?    Hydrocarbon and Ammonia detectors with alarms 

?    Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases 

?    Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated) 

?    Double Wall Ammonia St

orage tank design for containing ammonia liquid 

?    Release Containment/Control 

?    Emergency shutdown system 

?    Curbs or dikes to contain liquid releases 

?    Redundant equipment and instrumentation 

?    Atmospheric relief devices 

?    Release Mitigation 

?    Fire suppression and extinguishing systems 

?    Trained emergency response personnel 

?    Personal protective equipment 



Emergency Response Program Information 

IFCo's Emergency Response Plan (ERP) contains specific procedures for prompt response to emergencies that impact property and personnel inside and outside IFCo. The plan specifies how the emergency is handled, including corrective procedures, coordination with outside response agencies, and communication with the public. 



Periodic emergency response drills and compliance audits ensure that the plan is kept up-to-date, and changes are made as needed. Copies of the plan are available on the site HSE Website. The HSE Department coordinates training required by the plan. 



IFCo has a fire brigade team with personnel trained.  IFCo also has a Medical Response Team, HAZMAT team, and a Confined Space Entry Rescue Team. Team members attend routine required training that meet OSHA requirements for emergency responders; the training also complies with NFPA Standards.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

IFCo is committed to a high level of corporate citizenship, placing the highest priority on the safety of persons both within IFCo and in the neighboring community. IFCo strives to continually improve its safety program and to reward employees for outstanding safety performance. IFCo has adopted the Safe Start Program.  The program has been rolled out to all employee's on site (and to the new employees as they are hired).  IFCo is using the DuPont Safety Perception Survey as a way to measure gaps. The site has a Safety Committee that meets on a monthly basis.  The Safety Committee is comprised of employees from all areas of the plant.  The Safety Committee

has added subcommittees to focus on the 3 main items from the results of the sites 1st safety perception survey.  Those are: Communication, Rewards & Recognition, and Employee Participation.  Weekly Toolbox talks are held to present different safety topics.  Examples of a toolbox meeting are: recent incidents from IFCo and other plants, winter driving, using power tools, electricity. The site has continuous training in the Training Registration module within OCI's MESH system (company-wide HSE database).  The assigned courses are automatically sent out on a set frequency to the employees based on their job description.  Some topics that are part of IFCo's training portfolio include: Confined Space Entry Training, Industrial Exterior Fire Brigade Training, CPR, Pressurized Flammable Gas Fire Training, Hazmat Technician Training.  Table top exercises are held with local LEPC and Trans Canada (Natural Gas Pipeline into the IFCo plant).  Site wide safety drills are being conducted to discover if/and/or where the  deficiencies are.  Local emergency responders, LEPC's, hospitals and med-vac services are all invited to join IFCo employee's in these drills.  The site has been setup with Reverse 911 to notify the community should there be an incident that goes offsite.
